citeinfo.title: Proceedings of the invasive species workshop: the role of fire in the control and spread of invasive species

descript.abstract: The invasion of non-native plants, in combination with changes in the natural fire regime, is creating considerable challenges for land managers in the deserts of North America. Scientists discuss the relationship between invasive plants and fire in the changing deserts of North America. In portions of the Great Basin, Mojave, and Sonoran Deserts, native shrublands have been converted to grasslands full of non-native invasive species due to increased fire frequency. The invasive species create more fuel and help to perpetuate more frequent fires. Contrarily, lack of fire, climate changes, and historical overgrazing of livestock have allowed native woody shrubs to invade areas that have historically been perennial grasslands in the Chihuahuan Desert, and also allowed native trees to invade sagebrush steppe ecosystems in the Great Basin. Fire can be used to either control invasive species or to restore historical fire regimes, however, the potential for fire to promote the spread of invasive plants must be considered before fire is implemented as a management tool.
